DIV1.P: ERAMINTA. AN OPERA. As it is Perform'd at the HEATRE ROYAL IN LINCOLN's-INN FIELDS.
Written by Mr. CAREY, And set to MUSICK by Mr. JOHN CHRISTOPHER SMITH.
LONDON, Printed by J. WATTS; And sold by JOHN SHUCKBURGH at the Sun near the Inner-Temple-Gate in Fleetstreet. 1732.

DIV1.HEAD: To the Right Honourable RICHARD Earl of BURLINGTON.
DIV1.L: O BURLINGTON! to ev'ry Muse endear'd,
Behold the Bard by thy bright Influence chear'd;
sy his Life, and unconstrain'd his Lays.
hile his warm Heart glows grateful to thy Praise,
finds his Genius with his Fortunes mend,
d knows the Cause, for Burlington's his Friend.

CLOSER.SIGNED: Your LORDSHIP's ever obliged, and devoted humble Servant, H. CAREY.

DIV1.HEAD: THE ARGUMENT.
DIV1.P:
XARINO Prince of Cuba quits h Father's Court, for the Love o Teraminta a Beautiful Shepherdess, ta¦ing with him his Intimate Friend Crata¦der, who secretly becomes his Rival an creates such Misunderstanding between th Prince and Teraminta as occasions gre Distress; but the Appearance of Ardeli whom Cratander had ungenerously for sak after the most solemn Protestations of Co¦stancy, so confounds and convicts him, th he sincerely repents, with a Promise nev to desist till he has reconciled the Prin and Teraminta, which at last is happ
ffected. Xarino having sav'd the Life nd Empire of King Gozanes his Father, s requested to demand the utmost of his Wishes; he only asks Teraminta, which at first is denied him, but afterwards granted y means of a happy Incident, which ex∣orts a surprising Confession from Gonzanes, gives Teraminta to the Prince Ardelia to Cratander, and concludes the Opera.

LIST.LABEL: Gozanes, King of Cuba.
Xarino, his Son in Love with Tera∣minta.
Cratander, Favourite of Xarino, but secretly his Rival.
Teraminta, in Love with Xarino.
Ardelia, in love with Cratander, whom she follows in Disguise.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE I. SCENE, A pleasant Grove,

SP.SPEAKER: XARINO.
SP.L: Makes me abhor the Glories of a Court;
hese Groves are render'd far more pompous,

SP.SPEAKER: Cra.
SP.L: A Prince of such high Birth

SP.SPEAKER: Xar.
SP.L: Forbear, my Friend! can Courts, Pomp, or Titles,
Give me that Joy I find in Teraminta?

DIV4.HEAD: AIR.
DIV4.L: In a Plain with the Nymph I adore,
Than to reign, with Dominion and Pow'r,
A Monarch o'er Land, and o'er Sea.
No Throne can my Passion remove,
Or tempt me to change my Condition;
Her Heart is the Empire of Love,

SP.L: Why is Xarino thus preferr'd to me?
y did he trust me with this fatal Secret,
d tempt my Eyes to teach my Heart Defection?

DIV4.HEAD: AIR.
DIV4.L: All must submit to bright Beauty;
No Power can Love's Passion controul.
Talk not to Lovers of Reason;
Pallas comes quite out of season,

SP.SPEAKER: Ter.
SP.L: How Tasteless are the Beauties of the Spring,
w my Xarino is not here?
is Place is robb'd of all
And my fond Heart thrills quick to bid him we come.

SP.SPEAKER: Xar.
SP.L: If to these humble Plains, ye Gods!
Here let me dwell for ever,

SP.SPEAKER: Ter.
SP.L: You Shepherds make a Trade of Flattery.
The Court has spread its Influence o'er the Plai
And Cottagers have learnt to break their Vows.
Why does my Charmer treat me so,
What Falshood did I ever show?
Tho' all Mankind beside shou'd range,
I love so true, I cannot change.
But, 'tis the Pleasure of your Sex,
When most we love, you most perplex.

SP.SPEAKER: Ter.
SP.L: It is not that I know you false, Xarino,
But fear you shou'd be so.
n then a Virgin be too cautious?
t, 'tis unsafe to parley with Temptation,

DIV4.HEAD: AIR.
DIV4.L: Oh! then they approach with Respect;
But, when in our Hearts they've Admission,
They treat us with Scorn and Neglect.
So artful are Men to deceive;
So easy are Maids to believe.

SP.SPEAKER: Xar.
SP.L: She flies, but such a Cause assigns,
weet, tacit Oracle of my Felicity!

DIV4.HEAD: AIR.
DIV4.L: Of the Fair who already has mine.

SP.SPEAKER: Ard.
SP.L: Must I seek all the Corners of the Earth,
To follow one that flies me?
Hither I've trac'd my false One,
That robs me of his Heart:
May screen me from their Sight,
And give me, but I fear,

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE VII.
DIV3.STAGE: Teraminta follow'd by Cratander, Ardelia overhearing.

SP.SPEAKER: Cra.
SP.L: Why fly you thus from your Adorer?
You need but turn, and kill me with a Frown.

SP.SPEAKER: Ter.
SP.L: Oh that I were a Basilisk,
Thou should'st not long pursue me.

SP.SPEAKER: Ter.
SP.L: Why dost thou prosecute me thus?

SP.SPEAKER: Cra.
SP.L: Wou'd she look on him with those Eyes of Scorn,

SP.SPEAKER: Ard.
SP.L: Heav'n keep thee ever in this Mind.

SP.SPEAKER: Cra.
SP.L: Punish! by Heav'n he dares not;
Those Eyes have forc'd me to forget my Frie¦ship,
And any Chain is easy now to break;
All but my Love, and that repuls'd with Sco
Revenge shall follow, led by Desperation.

DIV4.HEAD: AIR.
DIV4.L: In the Heart of the Fair,
A Rival thus happy to reign;
For ever must sigh and complain.
Of this charming, this obstinate Maid.

SP.SPEAKER: Ard.
SP.L: What Scenes of Mischief agitate his Mind?
o shield this lovely Maid, and her Belov'd,
ow odious must these Actions render him,
nd yet, base as he is,

DIV4.HEAD: AIR.
DIV4.L: To love and not belov'd again,
Is sure a Grief, all Griefs by far exceeding;
What Torments must that Heart sustain,
Which burns for those that are for others bleeding?
Yet such is my inevitable Woe,
I love my Ruin, tho' I know 'tis so.Exit.

SP.P: These Eyes are Witness of her Falshoo

SP.L: It is not that I don't believe,

SP.P: O my Cratander! pity and excuse me.

SP.L: Think it was all a Vision,
To think a Woman cou'd be faithful,
s it for this I left my Father's Court,
There's such persuasive Magick in her Eyes,
But sure you'll see her first,
o let her know the Cause of your Departure.

DIV4.HEAD: AIR.
DIV4.L: In one who only slights my Care,
Yet still I adore her, still languish and die,
Sure never was Mortal so wretched as I!Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Cra.
SP.L: Shall pay full dear for her Disdain.
And make the Mischief more compleat.Exi
Sing on, sweet Warbler of the Grove!
sees I love, and now begins to slight me.
"Is gone to wed another, whose Possessions
"And let his Suff'rings meet that Pity dead,

DIV4.HEAD: AIR.
DIV4.L: Ye Nymphs! for my sake ne'er believe
Wou'd you remain secure and free,
And not Repentance taste like me,
DIV4.TRAILER: The End of the First ACT.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE I. SCENE A Plain: Tents, &c.

SP.SPEAKER: GOZANES.
SP.L: O Cowards! Dastards, to forsake y King,
And give your Country up —for Sha for Shame!
Sure as you fly you lose your Liberties,
If not your Lives — but if once more yon sal
The Fate of War may change, and we succeed
I'll foremost stand upon the brink of Danger;
Have I a Friend among you? let him follow,
If not, I'll singly purchase Death with Glory.

DIV4.HEAD: AIR.
DIV4.L: Robb'd of Freedom, Life is vain.
Fear! I scorn thee, if I die,
Dearly they my Life shall buy.Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Cra.
SP.L: as left me at full Freedom,
o try my Fate with Teraminta:
ve surely now more Hopes than ever;
Nay more, inclin'd to pity me;
This Disguise is no ill Plot,
But see! She comes, now for Dissimulation.

SP.SPEAKER: Cra.
SP.L: Just by my Cave they parted;
The different Stories of their Fortunes:
Is gone a Virgin to espouse
Of high Degree, and rich Possessions;
Scorn'd by the Fair he lov'd,
Wanders, he knows not, cares not whither.

SP.SPEAKER: Ter.
SP.L: Shall Strangers weep, and shall not I,
The Cause of all his Woe?
I'd freely drain these Eye-strings dry,
Why did I treat with such Disdain,
A Flame so pure and true?
Why love I still, yet love in vain,

SP.SPEAKER: Xar.
SP.L: Thus rous'd as from some strange illusive Dream,
wake astonisht, and with Shame reflect,
Upon my Follies past, O Teraminta!
In what a maze of Error, hast thou led me?
While I in Indolence by Charms inchanted,
Amus'd away my life's Meridian Splendor.
I shou'd have been conducting shining Legions,
In all the splendid Pomp of War array'd;
And not have suffer'd these sad Revolutions,
To fill my Country with such Scenes of Sorrow
My Father Captive! O Distracting Thought!
But 'tis resolv'd, I'll amply now atone,
Preserve his sacred Life, or lose my own.

DIV4.HEAD: AIR.
DIV4.L: I pant with an Ardor unknown.
And restore to my Father his Throne.

SP.SPEAKER: Ard.
SP.L: What is become of my Cratander?
Why dost thou fill my Soul with sad Conjecture
ke Birth from this pernicious Beauty?
he still lives, I kill her for my own.
t die she must; farewel Compassion!

SP.SPEAKER: Goz.
SP.L: Curst Fate of War! Uncertainty of Gra¦deur!
No Hopes of Liberty for lost Gozanes!
Here must I linger out a wretched Life;
Wretched indeed! for such a train of Sorrows,
Demonstrate me but born to know distress.
Surely some Vengeance from offended Heav'n,
Pursues me to the utmost Verge of Woe.
Oh ye vindictive Powers! that punish me,
Spare my Xarino, spare my hapless Son!
But lives he to be spar'd? that's the sad Questi

DIV4.HEAD: AIR.
DIV4.L: Let me behold my Son once more,
Or waft me to th' Elysian Shore,
On me your destin'd Vengeance shew,
Let him be spar'd and blest;

SP.SPEAKER: er.
SP.L: Come, O Sleep, my Eyelids close,
Lull my Soul to soft Repose,
Ease the Torments of my Breast.
Form so fair shou'd cause so much Distress?
call for Rage, and Pity comes.
ow coud'st thou leave me thus?

SP.P: Who cou'd kill her? It must not be.
O shield me, Heav'n! what's that?
A Friend, a poor afflicted Friend.

SP.SPEAKER: Ard.
SP.L: But drive me mad in Pity,
That I may have no Sense of Sorrow;
And with it all my Misery.

DIV4.HEAD: AIR.
DIV4.L: No Sense of Fear or Smart;

SP.P: All are not false; Cratander loves you.

SP.L: d place him prostrate at your Feet.

STAGE.HI: Discovers himself and seizes her Han

SP.L: Then I repent my cowardly Delays:
Consent can only soften me.Bearing her
Now by my Love, nay, by my Rage,
arm'd I dare thy Fury.Disarms her.
w busy Interrupter of my Bliss,
s I reward thy Insolence.Offers to kill her.
Strike home, and pierce a Heart
eary'd round the World I follow.
make amends for my past Falshood.

DIV4.HEAD: AIR for three Voices.

SP.L: And constant Love for Falshood change▪
If false or pure the Lover's Flame,
Their Joys as sure will prove the sa

DIV4.TRAILER: The End of the Second ACT.

SP.SPEAKER: XARINO.
SP.L: THIS Letter from my faithful Friend Cratander,
Brings Information of such monstrous Deeds,
As stagger ev'n Credulity it self;
Why did I, or indeed, why do I love thee?
Yet spite of all my past, and present Suff'rings;
So firmly art thou rooted in my Heart,
From thence I cannot tear thee —

DIV4.HEAD: AIR.
DIV4.L: O Cupid, why art thou pursuing
Such endless Designs on my Heart,
To make me so fond of my Ruin,
And doat on the Cause of my Smart?
In vain do I strive to remove her,
In spite of her Failings I love her,
She's charming, tho' false and unkind.

SP.L: Brings my dear Friend thus apt to his Xarino?
Wou'd you contain a Scorpion in your Arms?

SP.P: Thou art no Scorpion, but my Boso Friend.

SP.L: The more you call me Friend, the mo you wound me:
Do Justice to your self and Teraminta,
And call me Traitor, Villain as I am.
You talk'd of Teraminta, what of her?
lse in each Article as she is true.
e's Truth it self; all Constancy and Love.
e such a Scene of Villany to disclose,
ll make you idolize her very Name,
re your Offences numerous as the Stars,
ou wou'd speak to please me, speak of Love,

DIV4.HEAD: AIR.
DIV4.L: Laugh ye Valleys, smile ye Hills,
Tell it all the Groves around,
Chaste and faithful as she's fair,
Heav'n and Nature's Pride and Care;
Waft me Zephyrs to her Arms.Exeunt.

SP.L: Makes me conclude some Accident delays
Xarino, whom you thought an humble Shep
Wou'd he were still a Shepherd;
Ambition now will rob me of his Heart.
I know not what to think,
I fly to learn the Cause;
And bring you news of Consolation.
Sure I was born for Misery;
To taste the Bitterness of Life,
thout the least allay of Sweetness.
The Prince, fair Teraminta, begs excuse,
den Prevention stops his wisht Approach,
Talk not of Princes to a Shepherdess,
O'ersways your Patience, hear me, I beseech yo

SP.P: Wou'd I had never heard or him, you.

SP.L: And wou'd to Heav'n that neither or I
Had e'er beheld those most destructive Charms.
You wrong the Prince, too haughty Shepherde

SP.P: And so have I — I'll carry him yo Answer.

SP.L: Farewel Life, thou Vale of Woe,
Round Death's gloomy Realms to range,
Worse can never be the Change.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE VIII.
DIV3.STAGE: Xarino and his Party rescue him.

SP.L: y do these joyous Tears restrain my Eyes,
m fondly gazing on this darling Object?
I bring not only Liberty and Life,
double Empire to my dearest Father.
Compar'd to thee, Life, Liberty, and Empire
Compar'd to thee, Life, Liberty, and Empire
I know she loves to Desperation.

SP.P: What shall I tell the Prince?

DIV4.HEAD: AIR.
DIV4.L: In the absence of her Treasure,
All her Joy to Sorrow turns.Exit.

SP.L: he mourns in Solitude your Absence.

SP.P: O bring me to my Love.

SP.SPEAKER: Xar.
SP.L: But why with this Reserve appears my Charmer?
Why this Formality, this Air of Distance?
Does my Soul's Idol think that Birth or Titles
Can make the least Abatement in my Passion?
No, were I Monarch of the Globe's Extent,
'm still the same, her faithful fond Xarino.

SP.SPEAKER: Ter.
SP.L: So fond, and yet so dilatory:
That Passion must be cool indeed,

SP.SPEAKER: Xar.
SP.L: If to defeat a powerful Invader,
To save a Kingdom, and a Father's Life,
May be a Plea for Absence, that is mine.

SP.SPEAKER: Ter.
SP.L: My Fears were groundless, and my Hop are true,
Xarino's constant, and I still am happy.
hat not to recompense, wou'd be Ungrateful.
d him approach, and ask his Soul's Request.
y Son, to thee I owe my Life and Empire,
ntil I've recompens'd such great Deserts.
emand whate'er thou wilt, by yon high Heav'n,
ving my Duty to my Royal Parent,
ere is the Centre of my Soul's Ambition,
he only Object of my ardent Wishes.

SP.P: That Heav'n is just; there, there's the injur'd Face.
Did you then bid me ask but to deny me

SP.L: I grant thee any thing, but do conjure th
Let me ne'er see her more.
We go, dread Sir, for where her Sight's ¦fensive.

DIV4.HEAD: AIR.
DIV4.L: With her round the World will I wander,
For her ev'ry Hardship I'll bear;
Distress will but make me grow fonder,
While smiling she sweetens my Care.
Since then my fond Passion does grieve you,
O let me your Blessing implore;
And then I for ever will leave you,
No, never to trouble you more.

SP.L: Fear not, fair Nymph! but answer solemnly,
How this Enamel came in your Possession.
It was my dying Father's latest Token,
I wear it next my Heart.

SP.P: A Shepherd, Sir, and of no small P¦session.

SP.L: Rise, Princess, rise! thy Father was Shepherd,
But mighty Zantimenes King of Cuba.
ou need'st no Token to assert thy Birth;
h Feature in that Face bears strict Remem∣brance
the dear injur'd Monarch, for whose sake
Train of Vengeance has thus long pursu'd me;
as I robb'd thy Father of his Throne,
Rise, Sir, and spare my Blushes,
reater Gift than Empire's in your Pow'r;
e me Xarino, for I ask no more.
ad much rather choose to be your Daughter,
n to be Empress of the World's Extent.

SP.SPEAKER: r. and Xar.
SP.L: My Treasure, my Pleasure, my Joy, and Delight,
How great my Affection, thy Virtue how bright!
Fly Jealousy, fly, and Suspicion adieu,
For happy am I, as my Charmer is true.
O wondrous Force of Providence divine!
t still prevails in spite of Mens Design;
justly did it punish my Offence,
richly does it crown my Penitence?
Sceptre now resumes its rightful Place,

SP.SPEAKER: Cra.
SP.L: We come to share your Joy, and to co¦gratulate

SP.SPEAKER: Xar.
SP.L: Cratander, now our Cares are at an end
One happy Day our Nuptial Joys shall blend.
And may the fair Ardelia prove to thee,
As dear as Teraminta is to me.

DIV4.HEAD: CHORUS.
DIV4.L: Round our Hearts with Transports glow;
We can wish or Heav'n bestow.
